keyTakeAways: The incidence of pickleball-related eye injuries has increased by an estimated 405 cases per year from 2021 to 2024.
70% of eye injury cases in pickleball occur in adults aged 50 or older, contrary to expectations that youth athletes are most at risk.
Eye injuries can result from being hit by the ball, paddle, or falling, due to the fast-paced and small-court nature of the game.
Standardized eye protection guidelines are recommended to prevent up to 90% of sports-related eye injuries, similar to those in squash.
Players are often unaware of the risks, and lack of awareness is a major reason for non-use of protective eyewear.
Recommended protective eyewear should be made of shatter-resistant polycarbonate and meet the American Society for Testing and Materials' F3164 standard.
The study's limitations include a small sample size and reliance on emergency department data from participating hospitals only.
The main takeaway is raising awareness of preventable injuries, which could be mitigated through simple interventions like standardized guidelines and better education.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pickleball, now played by nearly 20 million Americans, has seen a sharp rise in eye injuries—up 405 cases annually from 2021 to 2024—according to a study published in JAMA Ophthalmology. The majority of injuries (70%) occur in adults 50 years or older, challenging the assumption that youth athletes are most at risk. Injuries stem from impacts with the ball, paddle, or falls due to the game’s fast pace and small court size. Experts including Dr. Corey Lacher and Dr. Daniel Henick emphasize that standard eye protection—especially shatter-resistant polycarbonate gear meeting ASTM F3164 standards—could prevent up to 90% of these injuries. A major barrier is lack of awareness among players, with many unaware of the risks. Recommendations include standardized guidelines, visible court signage, improved product accessibility, and role modeling by professional athletes. The study notes limitations, including a small sample and data from only participating emergency departments. Despite these, the key takeaway is the urgent need for public awareness and standardized safety protocols to prevent preventable, life-changing injuries.
title: Pickleball Eye Injuries Are on the Rise
